figure_1.title: Figure 1.
figure_1.caption: Prevalence of melanoma (A) and non-melanoma skin cancer (B) in five continents with the 1-year, 3-year, and 5-year analyses based on data from GLOBALCAN 2022.

figure_2.title: Figure 2.
figure_2.caption: Correlations between HDI and age-standardized morbidity and mortality in non-melanoma skin cancer (A) and melanoma of skin (B) based on data from GLOBALCAN 2022. The horizontal axis of the graph denotes the HDI levels. ASIR: Age-standardized incidence rates; ASMR: Age-standardized mortality rates; HDI: Human Development Index.

claims.sentence: In all countries and regions investigated, the ASIRs of melanoma of skin were relatively low below the age of 20 years but increased thereafter [Supplementary Figure 1, http://links.lww.com/CM9/C252].

Based on the prevalence in the 1-year, 3-year, and 5-year analyses, European showed the highest prevalence of cases followed by America, with prevalent cases peaking at age 60 years in Europe [Figure 1].
In contrast, in New Zealand and Australia, there was a sharp increase in ASIR observed after 30 years of age [Supplementary Figure 3, http://links.lww.com/CM9/C252].
In the Oceania countries and regions, with the exception of the Solomon Islands, there was a clear upward trend at about age 70 [Supplementary Figure 4, http://links.lww.com/CM9/C252].

With the increase of age, the prevalence of non-melanoma skin cancer in all countries and regions generally shows an upward trend, and non-melanoma skin cancer is more common among the elderly population [Figure 1].
Figure 2 contains a summary of results from the correlations performed between HDI and non-melanoma skin cancers and melanoma.

In all countries and regions investigated, the ASIRs of melanoma of skin were relatively low below the age of 20 years but increased thereafter [Supplementary Figure 1, http://links.lww.com/CM9/C252].

Based on the prevalence in the 1-year, 3-year, and 5-year analyses, European showed the highest prevalence of cases followed by America, with prevalent cases peaking at age 60 years in Europe [Figure 1].
In contrast, in New Zealand and Australia, there was a sharp increase in ASIR observed after 30 years of age [Supplementary Figure 3, http://links.lww.com/CM9/C252].
In the Oceania countries and regions, with the exception of the Solomon Islands, there was a clear upward trend at about age 70 [Supplementary Figure 4, http://links.lww.com/CM9/C252].

With the increase of age, the prevalence of non-melanoma skin cancer in all countries and regions generally shows an upward trend, and non-melanoma skin cancer is more common among the elderly population [Figure 1].
Figure 2 contains a summary of results from the correlations performed between HDI and non-melanoma skin cancers and melanoma.
